rows.title: What is Safeguarding?

title.eng: What is Safeguarding?

introduction.eng:
It is important to know the following guidelines for handling disclosures of abuse, neglect, and violence from participants:

1ï¸âƒ£ **Understand abuse, neglect and exploitation.**

â— **Abuse** refers to a deliberate act of maltreatment that can damage a childâ€™s security, wellbeing, dignity and development. Abuse includes all forms of physical, sexual, psychological and emotional maltreatment. (Save the Children definition)

â— **Violence** against children is defined as forms of physical or mental violence, damage and abuse, neglect or neglectful treatment or maltreatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse. (Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, 1990,
Article 19)

â— **Child exploitation** refers to using the child for economical or sexual benefit, for gratification or profit, often resulting in unjust, cruel and harmful treatment of the child. (Save the Children definition)

2ï¸âƒ£ **Know your organisationâ€™s child safeguarding policies and referral procedures.**

ğŸ“– All organisations should have or develop child rights safeguarding policies and referral procedures, including details on how to respond appropriately when a parent or child discloses abuse. 

ğŸ“ You should have accurate knowledge of all protocols and response plans. These will tell you what to do within your organisation if a parent or child reports abuse (e.g. who to report to, internal resources for supporting the child), as well as how to engage outside resources (e.g. local referral pathways, when to engage with authorities). 

ğŸ”‘ It is your responsibility to act regardless of whether you are responding to disclosures of past and/or present abuse. However, you are not responsible for resolving the situation on your own. It is important that you discuss the situation with your supervisor to agree on what steps to take next.

3ï¸âƒ£ **Ensure parents know that you are someone who can help.**

ğŸŒ·Parents participating in your sessions need to know that they can come to you for help, regardless of when abuse occurred. 

ğŸ‘‚You should make sure that they know that they can trust you and that you will listen and support them without judgement or any further harm.

rows.title: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

title.eng: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

introduction.eng:
**During disclosure:**

ğŸ’š Provide a safe environment in which the participant can share their story.

ğŸ‘‚ Listen carefully to the participant and take notes: what/when/where/who.

â— Determine if the participant is in immediate danger and what help is available.

ğŸ’™ Make sure that the participant feels that you believe him/her.

ğŸŒ· Let them know they have done the right thing by sharing their story with you.

âœ¨ Be supportive and free of judgement in your responses â€“ avoid blaming at all times!

â¡ï¸ Let the participant know that you will share what he/she told you with your supervisor to find a way to support and protect him/her.

ğŸ“ Explain what you are going to do next.

 âœ… Notify @global.supervisor_name.

introduction.eng:

âŒ Avoid engaging with alleged abuser â€“ that may make things worse and make next steps difficult. It could also jeopardise future legal proceedings.

rows.title: After Onboarding Session

title.eng: After Onboarding Session

introduction.eng: This chat session should happen on the same day or day after you complete the in-person onboarding session. As the first chat session, it offers a chance for parents to introduce themselves to the group.

section_title_1.eng: Add Ground Rules to the WhatsApp Group Description

section_text_1.eng:
Remember to add the ground rules to the WhatsApp Group Description. â€‹â€‹To add the ground rules to the Group Description, copy the following ground rules or use the ones agreed during the onboarding session: â€œTo make this a safe space for everyone, here are some ground rules:
 
âœ… What is said in the group stays in the group. You need to know that this group is private.
âœ… Accept each other. Everyone is different and has different experiences.
âœ… Share only what you feel comfortable sharing.
âœ… Feel free to ask questions!
âœ… Respect privacy of personal pictures and videos that are sent to the chat group. 
âœ… I am only here as an observer. I will not respond to questions about your parenting habits in this group or personally. However, if there is a message that will benefit the entire group, then I will share a general message here.â€

Open the WhatsApp group chat. Tap the group name. Tap the existing description, or tap Add Group Description. 
Paste the ground rules. Tap Save.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ˜ƒ Hi there! Welcome to our Crianza con Conciencia+ WhatsApp Group! 

Today we are introducing ourselves and our goals for the programme! â­ 

My name is [INSERT NAME] and my goal is to learn more about how to help my child go to bed by 8 every night.â°ğŸŒ™ 

Please share your name and your goal for Crianza con Conciencia+ using text or audio message.

message_guidance_1.eng:
Remember to fill in your name where it says [INSERT NAME] before sending your message. 

Allow some time for parents to share. Try to praise each response.
For example, you can say â€œThanks for the response, [Insert Name]!â€ or â€œGreat goal, [Insert Name]â€! You can also use simple emojis like ğŸ‘or ğŸ™‚

message_text_2.eng:
Every week, we will catch up at [INSERT TIME] on [INSERT DAY] to chat about our Crianza con Conciencia+ journey. 

ğŸ‘‹Please join to share how things are going, any challenges you experience, or just say hi! ğŸ˜Š

â°Does this time and day work for everyone?

message_guidance_2.eng: Add the time and day of the week before sending the message.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ˜ƒThank you so much for being part of our WhatsApp chat group! 

As your home practice, try to spend at least 5 minutes of One-on-One Time with your child each day. 

We can share about how it goes during our next chat session. 

ğŸ‘‹See you next week.

rows.title: Week 1: Self-Talk

title.eng: Week 1: Self-Talk

introduction.eng:
This session allows parents to notice how the things they think and say to themself impact their stress (â€œself-talkâ€)  and encourage positive self-talk to help manage stress. 
This skill is useful when parents are feeling overwhelmed, upset, or ashamed. There are three things to remember:

1- Encourage parents to practise this skill daily; it takes repetition to master.

2- Help parents understand that having negative thoughts and attitudes about their parenting is normal. Negative self-talk is a natural part of parenting. The important thing is to learn how to become more aware about when they are doing it. Like the redirect parenting skill - Catch it early before it gets worse!

Help them feel supported in the process of changing this behaviour by reminding them that this is a natural part of parenting, and that the skill may take some practise before it becomes second nature.

3- Children and teens learn from their parentsâ€™ example. How parents talk to themselves, teaches their kids how to talk to themselves. 

The home activity is for parents to notice when they engage in negative self-talk at least three times, and what the opposite the opposite, positive version of the same talk might be.

message_text_1.eng: ğŸ’šHello everyone! Our next chat session will be later today at [INSERT TIME]. Chat soon!

message_guidance_1.eng: Send this message in the morning on the day of the chat session. Insert the time for the chat before sending the message.

message_text_2.eng:
Hello, everyone! ğŸ˜ƒ
Welcome to our second chat session! Today, our topic is managing stress! ğŸŒ±
Stress is a normal part of being human, and parenting can add an extra layer of challenges. It's crucial to handle our stress well; otherwise, it can build up and affect our health, energy, and overall happiness. ğŸ˜¢
Everyone encounters stress. Think about your stress level today, using a scale from 1 ("No stress") to 10 ("Extremely stressed"), and feel free to share it with the group in the chat. Remember, every response is appreciated! We're all collaborating as a team! ğŸ’«

message_guidance_2.eng: Respond to the parents with a message of support for responding to the question. Feel free to encourage or share an answer to prompt parents to answer.

message_text_3.eng:
Thank you all for sharing your honest responses! ğŸ‰
We're all learning, and what matters most is that you're doing your best!
ğŸ’¡ This week, we're going to practise a skill that can help manage stress: self-talk.
ğŸ¤ Self-talk is the way we talk to ourselves in our head or out loud during stressful situations. Self-talk includes both things we say out loud to ourselves and thoughts we have in our minds.
It's quite easy to be unkind to ourselves, especially when we're tired, upset, or overwhelmed.
Can anyone share an example of negative self-talk?

message_guidance_3.eng: Allow parents to respond with an example, and choose an example that is 1) negative, and 2) referring to the parent.

message_text_4.eng:
Thanks for sharing that example!
Learning this skill will aid us in handling stress and feeling better when tough situations happen. Our kids pick up on how we talk to ourselves, even when we're not actively aware of it.
ğŸŒ·Have you ever considered how you talk to yourself during or after challenging events? Is it mostly positive, negative, or somewhere in between?

message_guidance_4.eng: Prompt parents to reply to these two questions. The goal is for parents to identify if they engage in negative self-talk and to learn that it is a common problem that many parents struggle with.

message_text_5.eng:
ğŸ“ This week, let's notice negative self-talk when it happens, and switch it to positive self-talk. Example:
**Negative Self-Talk:** "I was a bad parent today. I yelled at my teen for an honest mistake."
**Positive Self-Talk:** "Today was tough because I've been overwhelmed. I yelled at my teen, knowing it was an honest mistake. Next time, I'll pause before responding, ensuring I'm calm and in control."
ğŸ’¡ Notice how, in positive self-talk, the parent is more supportive and understanding rather than just labelling themselves a bad parent!
ğŸ  Now, it's your turn! Share a recent negative self-talk in the chat and provide a positive version.
By week's end, try to catch three instances of negative self-talk. Consider what a more positive version might be and see how it feels!
Any questions?

message_guidance_5.eng: Briefly read the participantsâ€™ responses and make sure they are not insulting themselves and generally follow the example above. Any instances of intent of self harm or harm of children should be reported appropriately.

rows.title: Week 4: Final Chat Session

title.eng: Week 4: Final Chat Session

introduction.eng:
This week is your final chat session with the group. It can be an emotional time for parentsâ€¦and for you. You should congratulate yourself for taking the parents through the Crianza con Conciencia+ journey and celebrate with them the positive changes in their lives and for their children. 

During this chat session, you will share the names of the two group admin to keep the WhatsApp Support Group ongoing, and handover the WhatsApp group administration rights to them. 

Remember, the WhatsApp groups are designed to support parent engagement in the Crianza con Conciencia+ chatbot. 

Before this chat session, you should have selected the two parents to lead the group. Enter the name of the parents after sharing the Group Message 3. If no one volunteered, see FAQ below. 

For next steps after selecting the group admin, see â€œHanding over to Group Adminâ€ on the homepage. 

You can choose to stay or leave the WhatsApp Group after the program ends.

message_text_1.eng: Hello! Our last chat session will be later today at [INSERT TIME]. See you then! ğŸ‘‹

message_guidance_1.eng: Send this message in the morning on the day of the chat session. Insert the time for the chat before sending the message.

message_text_2.eng:
ğŸ‘‹Hi everyone, welcome to the final chat session together on Crianza con Conciencia+. 

âœ¨ Take a moment to think back to the beginning of the programme. How have you and your child changed?

message_guidance_2.eng: Allow parents to share about the changes that they have experienced during the programme. You can give brief words of encouragement like â€œWonderful!â€ or â€œI am happy to hear that!â€ or even share celebration emojis like ğŸ‰or â­.

message_text_3.eng: Thank you for sharing your experiences. It is wonderful to see how much you have changed over the course of the programme. Remember that your parenting journey continues! ğŸ’š

message_text_4.eng: Although this is my last chat session with you, you are in good hands with your new chat group admin: [INSERT NAMES OF MODERATORS] ğŸ’™

message_text_5.eng:
I will now be exiting this WhatsApp Group. ğŸ‘‹

You are the best parents to your children *You can still complete your final Crianza con Conciencia+ Goals and Skills if you have not done so yet*. ğŸŒ±

We all face difficult situations sometimes, and these final parts of Crianza con Conciencia+ will help you and your child to get through them well. 

Youâ€™ve got this! â­You are doing a wonderful job as a parent. It has been a pleasure to be on this journey with you!

rows.title: If parents or group admin reach out to you after the group has ended.

title.eng: If parents or group admin reach out to you after the group has ended.

introduction.eng:
If parents or group admins reach out to you after the group has ended, it means that you have been helpful to them, which is amazing! 

Parents may see you as a source of support outside of school and Crianza con Conciencia+, but it is important to keep things balanced. 

Share this message to gently guide the parents to other places for support.

message_text_1.eng:
Hi!ğŸ˜ƒThank you for your message. 

My role with Crianza con Conciencia+ was limited. I unfortunately will not be further involved with the programme. 

If your WhatsApp Support group is still active, feel free to post your questions in the group. Other parents may be able to support you with helpful suggestions. ğŸ’¡

You can replay the Goal or Skill you are interested in by typing {MENU}.

rows.title: A parent cannot commit to the ground rules.

title.eng: A parent cannot commit to the ground rules.

introduction.eng:
Ground rules make your WhatsApp Support Group a safe space for everyone. 

If someone forgets the ground rules, send the message below to gently remind them of their importance. 

If necessary, share a group reminder about the importance of maintaining a positive and respectful space. 

If, despite reminders, the parent continues not to follow the rules, notify your supervisor. 

You can remove the parent from the group as the last option, done only when you feel it is necessary. For example, if a member repeatedly shares unrelated content, uses inappropriate language or is disrespectful to another member. 

If you do remove someone from the group, it should be handled with sensitivity and respect. Make sure you talk privately with the parent, remind the group about ground rules, and notify your supervisor.

message_title_1.eng: Send this reminder message to the group

message_text_1.eng:
Hello â­

ğŸ‘€ I'd like to take a moment to remind everyone about the importance of our group's ground rules. 

ğŸ’šThey're here to ensure that all of us feel comfortable sharing and maintain a positive environment. 

ğŸŒ±It's all about making this group a great place for everyone.

â—Please keep in mind that if the ground rules aren't consistently followed, we might need to consider removing members from the WhatsApp group for the well-being of all.

See you in the next chat session.

message_title_2.eng: Send this reminder message to the parent who broke the ground rule

message_text_2.eng:
Hello â­

ğŸ‘€ Creating a positive environment in our WhatsApp group is important, and that relies on everyone following the ground rules.

ğŸŒ± I believe in the strength of our community. 

However, if difficulties continue, I may have to consider removing you from the group. 

Let's work together to maintain a respectful and supportive atmosphere. 

See you in the next chat session.

message_title_3.eng: Send this message to the parent after removing them from the WhatsApp Group

message_text_3.eng:
Hello â­

ğŸ‘€ I have noticed despite reminders, the ground rules aren't being followed.

ğŸ’šYou can continue learning from Crianza con Conciencia+, but unfortunately I have removed you from the WhatsApp group to maintain a positive environment for everyone.

message_guidance_3.eng:
Notify your supervisor once you remove them. 
You can block the parent if they continue to reach out to you.

message_title_4.eng: Send this message to the group after removing the parent who broke the ground rule

message_text_4.eng:

ğŸ‘€ We want our group to be positive for everyone, and that means following the rules.

ğŸ’š Unfortunately, someone had to be removed because they weren't following the rules despite reminders.

Let's keep things respectful and supportive.See you in the next chat session!

rows.title: What if no one participates?

title.eng: What if no one participates?

introduction.eng:
Engaging parents in the group chat can sometimes be hard. Some parents may need a nudge to share their experiences or they might be busy with their schedules. 

If your chat goes silent after the prompt, consider sharing these ideas or suggestions:

â±ï¸I value your time and want to ensure our chat is convenient for everyone. 

â­Does this time work well for our conversations?

rows.title: Overview of the Crianza con Conciencia+ Programme

title.eng: Overview of the Crianza con Conciencia+ Programme

introduction.eng:
Welcome to the Crianza con Conciencia+ Positive Parenting Programme! 

Thank you for your commitment and dedication to supporting children and families in your community. 
You are a shining star!

section_text_1.eng:
This guide is for YOU!! 
A comprehensive guide to help you deliver Crianza con Conciencia+ to families around you. 
Steps on how to introduce caregivers to the programme, and support them
Specific information on the programmeâ€™s content.

section_text_2.eng:
It is important to follow this manual as closely as possible. However, manuals are only a guide to support you after what you have learned in the training workshop. 
What you deliver â€“ the content of the manual â€“ is only 20% of the programme. The rest 80%? Itâ€™s all about HOW you facilitate the programme and behave towards the parents.

section_text_3.eng: The core skills of a good facilitator are a mirror for parents to learn how to bring about the change we want to see in parents and the community. These include understanding stages of child development, praising and encouraging parents, using active listening skills, being consistent and compassionate, exploring problems, and finding solutions together.

section_text_4.eng:
Just as we say to the parents, â€œIt is what you do at home that makes the difference,â€ the same thing applies to you: â€œIt is how you interact with the parents in your group that makes the difference.â€ 

If you take the time to deliver a session before it begins, you will be more confident. If there is anything that you cannot remember or feel unsure of, contact another facilitator to practise with. 

Access the Facilitator Guide for your group by clicking on the icon above.

rows.title: Guide for In-Person Onboarding

title.eng: Guide for In-Person Onboarding

introduction.eng: The Onboarding Session sets the tone for the entire Crianza con Conciencia+ programme. It is important to create a space that is welcoming and safe for the participants to feel at ease and familiarise themselves with the programme.

rows.introduction: The Onboarding Session sets the tone for the entire Crianza con Conciencia+ programme. It is important to create a space that is welcoming and safe for the participants to feel at ease and familiarise themselves with the programme.

rows.title: How to Conduct Weekly WhatsApp Group Sessions

title.eng: How to Conduct Weekly WhatsApp Group Sessions

introduction.eng:
The Crianza con Conciencia+ programme includes WhatsApp Groups with parents with pre-scripted messages that you share each week from FaciNK. 

The aim of this group is to provide parents with extra support during their Crianza con Conciencia+ journey.

section_text_1.eng:
**Make sure you have done the following before the onboarding session starts:** 

- Save the names and WhatsApp numbers of the parents assigned to you on your phone (if available), so you can easily confirm details during the onboarding session. 

- Create your WhatsApp group (with temporary group name, icon, description). The name of each WhatsApp group has the same structure:
â€œCrianza con Conciencia+â€
Your group (B or D) 
A name selected by the group 

When you create your temporary group name, you will use the first 2 parts: "Crianza con Conciencia+â€ + your group. 

For example, if you have a WhatsApp group for group B, your temporary group name will be â€œCrianza con Conciencia+_GroupBâ€. 

You can keep your temporary group name or you can add a name to the temporary group name. For example, â€œCrianza con Conciencia+_GroupA_HappyFamiliesâ€.

section_text_2.eng:
**Before conducting weekly sessions, make sure you:** 

Create a WhatsApp Group during the onboarding session. 
Identify the ground rules for the WhatsApp Group

**Structure for the weekly chat session**: Week 0 (immediately after the onboarding session): Welcome, introductions, and reminder of home practice. Week 1: One-on-one time: Checking in on the home activity of spending 5 minutes of one-on-one time with their child. 

Week 2: Check-in: Connecting with parents on their progress with Crianza con Conciencia+. 

Week 3: Check-in: Connecting with parents on their progress with Crianza con Conciencia+, and identifying group admin to hand over the group after Week 4. 

Week 4: Final Chat Sessions: Sharing new group admin details, and closing.

**When to send the messages** 

You and your group will decide a time to chat during the onboarding session. Each chat session has a reminder message (Message 1) that you should send a few hours before the chat session. 

Send the remaining messages during the scheduled chat time.

section_title_3.eng: Share the messages in weekly session

section_text_3.eng:
Look for the "Weekly Sessions" section on FaciNK homepage

Find the specific week you want to share and click on it.

Once you're on the content for that week, locate the "Share" icon. It should look like an arrow pointing upward or a box with an arrow, and it's used to share content. Click on the "Share" icon.

In the menu that appears, select "WhatsApp" as your sharing option.

Choose your Crianza con Conciencia+ Support Group from the list. 

Before you hit the "Send" button, make sure to add or change any necessary information like your name. 

Finally, click the "Send" button to share the content with your Crianza con Conciencia+ Support Group.

section_title_4.eng: Get Help with WhatsApp Support Group

section_text_4.eng:
If you require help while moderating your WhatsApp Support Group, the weekly sessions provide a list of FAQ and potential solutions.

If you need support responding to a challenge shared by the parent during your weekly chat session, see â€œCommon Challengesâ€ on the homepage. 

Follow the same instructions as Sharing Weekly Messages to share the solutions to the challenges. 

If you encounter a challenge not covered in the weekly session, kindly contact your supervisor for further guidance.

rows.title: How to hand over to Group Admin

title.eng: How to hand over to Group Admin

introduction.eng:
Once 2 volunteers to be group admin are selected, schedule a WhatsApp call with the them.

When youâ€™re done with the call, you can send the guidelines as messages to remind them what you discussed.

section_title_1.eng: What to cover in the WhatsApp Call?

section_text_1.eng:
Thank the parent for volunteering to lead the WhatsApp group.  

While engaging with other parents in the group, keep the following in mind:
ğŸ”µGreet parents when engaging with them.
ğŸ”µRespect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values and circumstances.
ğŸ”µEncourage parents to share and respond to each other - and praise them for it.
ğŸ”µRemind parents of ground rules when needed.
ğŸ”µModel the behaviour you want to see among the parents.

If the parent needs any prompts for discussion, share the following: 

Let us celebrate our successes! What was something positive you experienced when you tried one of the Crianza con Conciencia+ skills with your child?

Trying out new skills can be hard at first. What was something difficult that you experienced when you tried a Crianza con Conciencia+ skill with your child at home?
Remind the parent that they are not obligated to respond to messages all times. Participants may send messages at any time during the week. To keep your workload manageable, you can respond to messages once or twice a day, depending on your schedule. 

Ask them if they have any questions. 

Remind the parent that unfortunately, you will no longer be able to participate in the WhatsApp group.

message_title_1.eng: Send this message after your WhatsApp Call

rows.title: How to Report on Programme Delivery

title.eng: How to Report on Programme Delivery

introduction.eng:
The FaciNK also makes reporting on the delivery of Crianza con Conciencia+ much easier than paper forms.

After adding each parentâ€™s name to the App, you will be able to report on their participation during in-person and WhatsApp group sessions.

You will also report on your own experience including the time spent conducting each session and whether you were able to do all the activities in the session.

section_text_1.eng:
Select the profile icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Choose â€œAbout youâ€ 

Type your name under â€œYour nameâ€ 

Select your state from the dropdown menu 
Tap Save

section_text_2.eng:
Select the profile icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Choose â€œAdd Parentâ€

Enter parent details in the form. To enter the parentâ€™s unique identifier (UID), ask them to text â€œIDâ€ on Crianza con Conciencia+. Copy the 6-digit number into the parent profile.

section_text_3.eng:
If two parents from the same family are participating in the programme, together, you must link their accounts. 

Once you have added the first parent profile, to add a second parent, select â€œAdd Parentâ€

Enter parent details in the form. To enter the parentâ€™s unique identifier (UID), ask them to text â€œIDâ€ on Crianza con Conciencia+. Copy the 6-digit number into the parent profile. 

Select â€œAdd Co-Parentâ€

Select the co-parent from available parent user profiles. 

Select â€œSaveâ€

*Both parent profiles will be updated to note the co-parent.*

section_text_4.eng:
Select the pencil icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Select whether you are reporting on an in-person or WhatsApp session with your parents. 

Choose which session you are reporting on. 


Complete the report 

â°Specify the time spent on preparation, travel, and actual session delivery. 

âœ…Check the activities you completed (in-person) or number of messages you sent (WhatsApp Group)

ğŸ”µSelecting the parents who participated in the session:

For in-person sessions, â€œparticipationâ€ is defined as parents who attended the session, in part or whole. 
For the WhatsApp group, â€œparticipationâ€ is defined as parents who have sent at least 1 message during the chat session. 

If you do not see a parentâ€™s name, then you need to add that parent to the App (see above).

section_text_5.eng:
Only edit an attendance report if you have made a mistake.

Select the pencil icon from the bottom of the navigation bar. 

Select whether the session you want to edit was an in-person or WhatsApp session. 

Select the session that you want to edit.

Your previous selections will appear. You can now edit your selections and select â€œSaveâ€

rows.title: Spending one-on-one time

title.eng: Spending one-on-one time

introduction.eng:
Parenting can be challenging and many obstacles can get in the way.

Remember, your job isn't to solve their problems, but enable a conversation between parents to support one another. ğŸ”„

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for spending one-on-one time that we have encountered previously when delivering the programme. You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I didnâ€™t have enough time to spend one-on-one time.

message_text_1.eng: Thank you for sharing. It can be hard to find time, especially when you have work, chores, and other responsibilities to do. ğŸ˜” You could try finding a chore to do together.

message_title_2.eng: My child did not want to spend time with me.

message_text_2.eng: Thank you for sharing. It feels sad when your child doesn't want to spend time with you. ğŸ˜” Try suggesting a fun activity to do together.

message_title_3.eng: All my child wanted to do was watch T.V. or play with a gadget.

message_text_3.eng:
It can be tough when your child seems focused on watching TV or playing with a gadget all the time. ğŸ˜Ÿ 

To connect with them and understand their interests, try asking them to show you something cool on the gadget. 

It's a simple way to engage with their world and spend time together. ğŸ“º

message_title_4.eng: My child did not want one-on-one time to end.

message_text_4.eng:
I understand it can be tough when your child does not want one-on-one time to end. ğŸ˜£To make things smoother, try being clear about how much time you have together and give a gentle warning when the time is about to end. â°

To help you with managing your childâ€™s behaviour, consider making â€œSupport My Childâ€™s Positive Behaviourâ€ as your next parenting goal once you finish your current goal.

message_title_5.eng: My child wanted to do activities that I could not do.

message_text_5.eng:
I can imagine it's challenging when your child wants to do activities that you find difficult. ğŸ˜”

 A simple solution is to ask your child if you can join in by watching. 

This way, you're still involved and supportive, even if you can't participate directly. ğŸ¤

rows.title: Praising your child

title.eng: Praising your child

introduction.eng:
It is normal for parents to feel uncomfortable or have challenges when praising their children. They may at first think that praise will either inflate their children or is not part of their culture. 

It is important to remember that there are many different ways to praise children. Crianza con Conciencia+ focuses mainly on praise as a method to reinforce positive behaviour. We praise the behaviour more than just the child!

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for praising your child. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I forgot to praise my child.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ’šIt can be difficult to juggle all the different things we need to do. 

ğŸŒ±Next time you spend one-on-one time, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. 

â˜€ï¸You can even say, â€œThank you for
spending time with me!â€

message_title_2.eng: I felt embarrassed or weird when praising my child.

message_text_2.eng:
â­Itâ€™s normal to feel uneasy about doing new things.

ğŸŒ·This is especially true of praise when we are not used to hearing it ourselves. 

ğŸ‘€But it will get easier with practice,I promise!

message_title_3.eng: I canâ€™t think of anything to praise my child.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ””Start small! You donâ€™t have to select anything big to praise. 

ğŸ’¡Find a simple behaviour that your child does that you are happy about and tell them. Even something that they already do. 

â™¥ï¸ It will make a difference!

rows.title: Talking about feelings

title.eng: Talking about feelings

introduction.eng:
It is completely normal for parents to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Parents may be trying to recognise their emotions and communicate about them for the first time here.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for talking about feelings. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: My child did not want to share their emotions.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ’šI understand that sharing feelings is challenging when itâ€™s new. 

ğŸŒ±Be patient and keep providing them with the opportunity to start sharing. 

â˜€ï¸Be a model for your children by sharing your own feelings.

message_title_2.eng: I felt uncomfortable talking about my own feelings

message_text_2.eng:
â­It's okay to feel uncomfortable talking about your own feelings. 

ğŸ‘€A simple way to start is by using 'I feel...' 

ğŸŒ·For example, you could say, "I feel happy when we spend time together." Starting small like this can make it easier.

message_title_3.eng: Others in the household donâ€™t think itâ€™s a good idea to talk about emotions.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ””You can try talking to them about why it might be a good idea. 

ğŸ’¡Encourage them to try it first. Sometimes, just giving it a try can help everyone understand each other better.

message_title_4.eng: Others in the household donâ€™t think itâ€™s a good idea to talk about negative emotions.

message_text_4.eng:
ğŸ””Maybe you can have a chat with them about why it could be a good idea. 

ğŸ’¡Encourage them to give it a try! Talking openly about feelings can help everyone understand each other better.

message_title_5.eng: I donâ€™t know how to name some of the feelings I am experiencing.

message_text_5.eng:
âœ¨Naming feelings can be tough. 

ğŸ”„Try combining words you know, like happy or sad, and think about where you feel it in your body. 

ğŸ”´For example, if your chest feels tight, it might be stress. 

ğŸ”¶It's okay not to have all the words â€“ describe it the best you can.
